item.title: This Toshiba 55-Inch 4K Fire TV Is Only $200 For Prime Big Deal Days
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

You don't have to wait for Prime Big Deal Days to kick off on October 7 to start saving, as the Toshiba 55-Inch Class C350 LED Smart Fire 4K TV is already down to its lowest price ever at Amazon. The LED TV is just $200 (was $400), and several other sizes are also discounted ahead of the shopping event--including nice price cuts on the 75-inch and 65-inch variants. Despite being official Big Deal Days early offers, these budget-friendly Toshiba 4K TVs are shipped and sold by Best Buy

Toshiba 55-Inch Class C350 LED Smart Fire 4K TV

$200 (was $400)

This LED 4K TV offers AI upscaling for non-4K content, support for Dolby Atmos, Dolby Vision, and an Ultimate Motion feature that's said to reduce blur during fast-moving scenes. It has a dedicated Game Mode with variable refresh rates and reduced latency. Just keep in mind that the C350 is limited to 60Hz refresh rate.

As a Fire TV, you'll have quick access to popular apps and streaming services. The TV also includes a Voice Remote with Alexa, allowing you to use voice commands to find your favorite content.

The 55-inch model is seeing the best deal, as it's a full 50% off its usual asking price. In fact, it's cheaper than the 50-inch model (which is $220). But if this size isn't right for your space, there are several other options to choose from, including a 65-inch for only $300 and 75-inch for $430. Note that the 55-inch discount is exclusive to Prime members.

Toshiba Class C350 LED Smart Fire 4K TV

  • 43-inch -- $159 ($300)
  • 50-inch -- $220 ($350)
  • 55-inch -- $200 ($400)
  • 65-inch -- $300 ($530)
  • 75-inch -- $430 ($730)

Several other Amazon devices are on sale ahead of Big Deal Days, including Luna Controllers, security cameras, and smart displays. There's also a long list of other Fire TV devices up for grabs, including the Fire TV Stick HD, Fire TV Stick 4K, and Fire TV Stick 4K Max. Both are capable of turning your HD TV into a smart TV, though the 4K Max is the most compelling due to its support for Wi-Fi 6E, additional storage, and included Alexa Voice Remote Enhanced.

For something even more premium than the Fire TV Stick, check out the Fire TV Cube, which offers everything you'd find on the Fire TV Stick 4K Max plus access to a hands-free Alexa system, inputs for additional devices (like your cable box or gaming consoles), and an ethernet port.

Consider pairing your Fire TV with the Fire TV Soundbar or Soundbar Plus. The Soundbar Plus is the better option right now, as it's seeing an impressive $100 price cut. The 3.1 channel device features a built-in subwoofer, supports Dolby Atmos, and offers a dialogue enhancer feature for improved clarity. The standard TV Soundbar, meanwhile, doesnâ€™t include a subwoofer but is a nice step up from most built-in TV speakers.

Amazon Fire TV Streaming Devices

  • Fire TV Stick HD -- $18 ($35)
  • Fire TV Stick 4K -- $25 ($50)
  • Fire TV Stick 4K Max -- $40 ($60)
  • Fire TV Cube -- $100 ($140)
  • Fire TV Soundbar -- $90 ($120)
  • Fire TV Soundbar Plus -- $150 ($250)
  • Fire TV Alexa Voice Remote -- $25 ($35)

And if you want some movies to watch on your new 4K TV, Amazon has a bunch of 4K Blu-rays for $15 or less as part of its early Prime Big Deal Days sale.

  • Get Popular Movies On 4K Blu-Ray For $15 Or Less At Amazon This Week
  • ROG Xbox Ally X Preorders In Stock At Best Buy, Sold Out Everywhere Else (September 27)
  • New Magic: The Gathering Final Fantasy Chocobo Bundle & Scene Boxes Up For Preorder
  • + Show More More Gaming, Tech, and Entertainment Deals & Preorders Links (5)
  • You Can Get The $60 Lego Game Boy Early From Amazon
  • Complete History Of Middle-Earth Drops To All-Time Best Price For Big Deal Days
  • The Shining's New 4K Steelbook Edition Is Back In Stock At Walmart, Releases Next Week
  • Nintendo Switch 2 Mario Kart Bundle In Stock At Amazon With Same-Day Delivery
  • Sonic Racing: CrossWorlds Amazon-Exclusive Edition Is In Stock On Launch Day

item.title: Call Of Duty: Warzone Is Returning To Its Blackout Roots
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

We're getting a blast from the past when a future major Call of Duty: Warzone update drops in Spring 2026. "A bold new experience" will come to the battle royale, inspired by the Black Ops 4 battle royale mode, Blackout.

"Call of Duty: Warzone is bringing a bold new experience in Spring of 2026 inspired by the original Blackout, set on Avalon," reads a post from the official Call of Duty X account.

Call of Duty: Black Ops 4 was the first Call of Duty game to feature a battle royale mode. Launching after the battle royale boom in 2017, Blackout had 100 players drop onto a gigantic map to fight for their lives until only one player or team was left standing.

Black Ops 4's battle royale map, Avalon, will also be returning. It featured fan-favorite named locations like Nuketown Island, as well as more generic locales like a train station and construction site. Avalon has changed several times over the years, and we don't know how it might change for this 2026 release, so none of the locations from the original map are guaranteed to return. While Avalon is positively viewed by many in the Warzone community, Verdansk and other Warzone maps are often viewed more favorably.

Warzone is also getting a new Resurgence map alongside Black Ops 7. The new map, Haven's Hollow, will be smaller than Fortune's Keep but larger than Rebirth Island.

Call of Duty: Black Ops 7's open beta begins this weekend, with the official start times finally revealed. During the beta, you'll also get a taste of the Zombies mode and a feel for how explosive body shields are.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Peak Players Are Passing Time At The Airport In Increasingly Elaborate Ways
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

No one likes waiting, especially when there's nothing to do to pass the time. Peak developer Landfall Games had that same thought when working on Peak's most recent DillyDally update. It adds a handful of activities to lobbies while waiting for other players to join, including a basketball hoop, photo booth, and chess pieces.

Players went straight to work with the chess pieces, but not according to official rules the classic game uses.

"My friend and I got bored after we finished a climb," wrote Imanthony89 in a post on the Peak subreddit. "Used all the chess pieces and bing bong. That's a queen and a few pawns above the rafters"

The update released last week, and social media was flooded with chess pieces stacked ceiling-high in the airport lobby over the weekend. Peak's physics system, which can lead to some quirky antics on climbs, turned out to be perfect for some extracurricular activities for the scouts.

Peak lobbies are set in airport waiting areas, as the game begins with a playful loading-screen plane crash that sets you and your friends off on your journey to summit a procedurally generated mountain. The climb is almost never easy, so it makes sense that scouts should have some fun while waiting in the terminal.

Landfall Games and publisher Aggro Crab have released a few updates since Peak became a massive hit when it launched in June. A new biome, the Mesa--complete with tornadoes, scorching heat, and scorpions--was added in August. Another biome has also been teased, but no confirmed details have been shared yet.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
